rules.natural: If the project has zoning approval, then the project completed the foundation phase.
Provided that the project has zoning approval, the project has building permit approval.
Either the project has zoning approval or the project has environmental approval.
If the project has delay coverage insurance, then the insurance policy has active coverage.
Assuming the insurance policy has active coverage, if failing to complete the foundation phase implies not being on schedule, then the project incurred a cost overrun.
Provided that steel material is available at the site, the crew can proceed with foundation work.
If steel material is available at the site, then the engineer approved an alternative composite material.
In the event that the engineer approved an alternative composite material, the crew cannot proceed with foundation work.
If the project has environmental approval, then the project is on schedule.
Provided the contractor submitted a zoning application, if the project has building permit approval, then the project is on schedule.
Either the contractor submitted a zoning application or the contractor submitted an environmental application.
Assuming the contractor submitted an environmental application, if the project has building permit approval, then the project is on schedule.
If the project has complete funding, then the project is on schedule.
In the event that the project has a steel material delay, steel material is available at the site.
Provided that the contractor received a deadline extension, if there is a steel material delay for the project, then the project has a schedule delay.
Either the contractor received a deadline extension or the contractor received a penalty.
If it is not the case that receiving a penalty implies that a steel material delay leads to a schedule delay, then the owner terminated the contractor's contract.
In the event that the project does not have complete funding, the project has a steel material delay.

facts.natural: The project has delay coverage insurance.
It is not the case that the owner terminated the contractor's contract.
It is not the case that the project incurred a cost overrun.
The project does not have a schedule delay.

(A1 → A12).natural: If the project has zoning approval, then the project completed the foundation phase.

(A1 → G).natural: Whenever the project has zoning approval, the project is on schedule.

(A1 ∨ A2).natural: Either the project has zoning approval or the project has environmental approval.

(A12 → G).natural: Should the project complete the foundation phase, the project is on schedule.

(A14 → (¬(A12 → G) → A13)).natural: Given that the project has delay coverage insurance, if it is not the case that completing the foundation phase implies being on schedule, then the project incurred a cost overrun.

(A14 → A15).natural: If the project has delay coverage insurance, then the insurance policy has active coverage.

(A15 → (¬(A12 → G) → A13)).natural: Assuming the insurance policy has active coverage, if failing to complete the foundation phase implies not being on schedule, then the project incurred a cost overrun.

(A16 → A17).natural: Provided that steel material is available at the site, the crew can proceed with foundation work.

(A18 → ¬A17).natural: In the event that the engineer approved an alternative composite material, the crew cannot proceed with foundation work.
